In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Mission Bell Winery's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Mission Bell Winery has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Mission Bell Winery has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Mission Bell Winery now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Mission Bell Winery employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Mission Bell Winery will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of process hazards in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Mission Bell Winery has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the covered processes. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia
The covered processes at the Mission Bell Winery facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the covered processes and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History
Mission Bell Winery has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

Safety Systems

Relief Valves

Four (4) Squibb Taylor pressure relief valves are installed on the ammonia storage tank. The relief valves on the vessel relieve at 265 psig and discharge to the atmosphere. Refer to the Relief System Design and Design Basis documentation for more information.

A relief valve is installed on the Neutralization Tank piping to allow for the relief of overpressure due to ammonia expansion resulting from high heat. The relief valve discharges into the Neutralization Sample Tank which is filled with water.

Analog Gauge

An analog gauge is installed on the ammonia storage tank. The gauge provides the ability for operators to monitor vessel fill percentage.

Excess Flow Valves

Excess flow valves are safety devices which are designed to close in the event of a piping failure to prevent flow. Excess flow valves are located on the liquid and vapor piping, close to the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage Tank.

Emergency Shutoff Valves

The emergency shutoff valves are connected to a pull station and controlled pneumatically. The operator can isolate the tank by activating any of the five (5) pull stations.

The main suction accumulators are each equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high liquid level in the vessel. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.

Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)

Process Chemistry

The Neutralization Process at Mission Bell Winery involves the storage and transfer of anhydrous ammonia to two (2) neutralizing tanks. The neutralizing tanks contain sulfuric acid waste from the ion exchange process. When anhydrous ammonia is injected into the neutralizing tanks, the theoretical reaction is as follows:

 2NH3 + H2SO4 → (NH4)2SO4

The product resulting from this reaction is a dilute solution of ammonium sulfate at a pH range between 5 and 9.

Screw Compressor Safety Devices

Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.

High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.

Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Safety Systems

Emergency Control Box

The Emergency Control Box (ECB) is installed in the Black Grape system on the south side of the machinery area. The ECB contains three (3) valves:

Valve A: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve B: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve C: Diffusion Tank Isolation Valve

If necessary, these valves can be used to achieve the following results:

Valves A and C are used to relieve the pressure of the high side of the system to the diffusion tank. 

Valves B and C are used to relieve the pressure of the low side of the system to the diffusion tank.

Valves A and B are used to equalize the pressure from the high pressure receiver to the low pressure chillers.

Relief Valves

All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:

All relief valves are connected to a common manifold which terminates into an ammonia diffusion tank; 

Many relief valves are equipped with a rupture disc and non-resetting gauge to assist in recognizing that an overpressure event has occurred. The rupture discs are installed upstream of each relief valve and are designed to break at the relief valve set pressure. Once the rupture disc gauge has been broken, the gauge needle will move to the burst zone, indicating that the relief valve has lifted. The gauges can be manually reset;

The main suction accumulators are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the main suction accumulators contain low pressure vapor ammonia.

Liquid Transfer Vessels

The purpose of each liquid transfer vessel is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration systems back to the high pressure receivers. The liquid transfer vessels receive liquid from the main suction accumulators. Once the liquid level in the liquid transfer vessels reaches the float switch, the three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer vessels to become subject to high pressure and activating the transfer pumps which moves the liquid to the high pressure receivers. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer vessels and transfer pumps can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.

Compressors

The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the chillers to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the main suction accumulators or chillers and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.

Evaporative Condensers

The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the chillers to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receivers. The condensers use air and water to cool

ach accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated chillers. Liquid and vapor returned from the chillers is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the main suction accumulator or supplied directly to the compressors. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Plate and Frame Heat Exchanger

The purpose of the plate and frame heat exchanger is to remove heat from the glycol solution being pumped through it. The plate and frame heat exchanger receives liquid from a main suction accumulator  where it flows through the channels in the plates and absorbs the heat from the glycol solution on the opposite side of each plate. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the plate and frame heat exchanger and is returned to the main suction accumulator. Under normal conditions, the plate and frame heat exchanger contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Shell and Tube Heat Exchangers

The purpose of each shell and tube heat exchanger (chiller) is to remove heat from the wine or glycol solution being pumped through it. The chillers receive liquid from a flooded accumulator where it is contained within the shell of the heat exchanger and surrounds the tubes containing wine or glycol. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the chillers and is returned to the flooded accumulators. Under normal conditions, the chillers contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Main Suction Accumulators

The purpose of the main suction accumulators is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The main suction accumulators receive vapor from the flooded accumulators and separate any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. 1.2.3 Description of Covered Processes

1.2.3.1 Ammonia Refrigeration

Each shell and tube wine chiller and the plate and frame heat exchanger is equipped with an accumulator as required for flooded operation. Most control valve groups are located near the equipment to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is located in outdoor machinery areas. 

Process Chemistry

The refrigeration systems employed at Mission Bell Winery are configured for flooded operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in the systems is summarized below:

High Pressure Receivers

The purpose of each high pressure receiver is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration systems. The high pressure receivers receive high pressure liquid from the condensers and supply high pressure liquid to each shell and tube heat exchanger. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the processes at any given moment. The high pressure receivers are each equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Flooded Accumulators

1.2 Process Descriptions
1.2.1 Facility Overview
Mission Bell Winery is a large-scale production winery in Madera, CA which employs anhydrous ammonia processes that are subject to the RMP, PSM, and/or CalARP regulations.

1.2.1.1 Ammonia Refrigeration

Mission Bell Winery utilizes closed-circuit, ammonia refrigeration processes to provide cooling capacity to various chillers located throughout the site. Each system is located outdoors, with the compressors, high pressure receiver(s), and condenser(s) located in a machinery area. Most of the system names correspond with the wine chillers associated with the system. The processes provide refrigeration capacity to the following: 

Black Grape: (8) Shell and tube wine chillers

Chillers - 550: (14) Shell and tube wine chillers
